Open your ears and listen to the words of the wise,
and set your heart on the knowledge that I offer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for it is pleasant when you keep my words deep within you,
and you have them ready on your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Today I make my words known to you—yes, to you,
so that your trust will be in the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have I not written to you already with advice and knowledge,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
in order to make accurate, true words known to you,
so that you may reply with true words to those who sent you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not rob a poor person because he is poor,
and do not crush an oppressed person in court,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because the Lord will defend their cause,
and he will rob those who rob them of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be friends with a hothead.
Do not go along with someone who has a hot temper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do, you will learn his ways
and set a trap for yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be among those who shake hands to guarantee debts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do not have enough to repay,
why should your bed be taken out from under you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not move an ancient boundary marker
    that your ancestors made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a person who is efficient in his work?
He will serve kings.
He will not serve nobodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When you sit down to eat with a ruler,
pay close attention to what is put in front of you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and put a knife to your throat if you have a big appetite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not crave his delicious food.
That food is deceptive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not wear yourself out getting rich.
Have the good judgment to know when to stop.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will your eyes get a glimpse of wealth before it is gone?
No, it will sprout wings for itself.
Like an eagle it will fly away into the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not eat the food of a miser.
Do not crave his delicious food,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he is calculating how much things cost him.
So when he says to you, “Eat and drink,”
he does not mean it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will vomit up the little bit you ate
and spoil your pleasant conversation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not speak within earshot of a fool,
because he will despise your sensible words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not move an ancient boundary marker,
and do not enter the fields of the fatherless,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because their Redeemer is strong.
He will defend their cause against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Apply your heart to discipline
and your ear to words that give knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not withhold discipline from a child,
for if you strike him with a rod, he will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strike him yourself with a rod,
and you will rescue his soul from death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, if your mind is wise,
my mind will rejoice as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My heart will celebrate
when your lips speak upright things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not allow your heart to envy sinners.
Instead, always fear the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, there is a future,
and your hope will never be cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, my son, and be wise,
and keep your heart on the straight way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be among those who drink too much wine,
or those who eat too much meat,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because a drunk and a glutton will become poor,
and drunken stupor dresses a person in rags.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to your father, who gave you life,
and do not despise your mother when she is old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Buy truth and do not sell it.
Buy wisdom, discipline, and knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The father of a righteous child will celebrate greatly.
One who fathers a wise son will find joy in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your father and your mother will find joy,
and she who gave birth to you will celebrate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, give me your heart,
and let your eyes be pleased with my ways,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because a prostitute is a deep pit,
and an immoral woman is a narrow well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is also like a robber waiting to ambush someone,
and she multiplies unfaithful men among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has trouble? Who has misery?
Who has quarrels? Who has complaints?
Who has wounds for no reason? Who has glazed eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who linger over wine,
those who go to search for mixed wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not look at wine when it is red,
when it sparkles in the cup,
when it goes down smoothly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later it bites like a snake,
and it strikes like a venomous viper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your eyes will see strange things,
and your mind will say senseless things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be like someone who tries to sleep in the middle of the sea,
like someone who tries to sleep at the top of a ship’s mast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They struck me, but I felt no pain.
They beat me, but I was not aware of it.
When will I wake up, so that I can try it again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not envy evil people,
and do not wish to be with them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because their hearts plan violence,
and their lips speak trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With wisdom a house is built.
With understanding it is established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With knowledge its rooms are filled with every kind of riches,
both valuable and appealing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wise person grows strong,
and a knowledgeable man becomes more powerful,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because advice prepares you for battle,
and many advisors bring victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wise decisions are out of reach for a stubborn fool.
In court he cannot open his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever plans evil will be called a master schemer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A foolish scheme is a sin,
and a mocker is disgusting to people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you fail to act in the day of trouble,
your strength is too little.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rescue captives condemned to death,
and spare those staggering toward slaughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you say, “We did not know about this,”
won’t the one who weighs motives notice?
Won’t the one who guards your life know about it,
and won’t he repay people according to what each one has done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, eat honey, because it is good.
Flowing honey is sweet on your palate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Know also that wisdom is sweet for your soul.
If you find it, then there is a future for you,
and your hope will never be cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be like the wicked who attack the home of the righteous.
Do not destroy his resting place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because a righteous person may fall seven times, but he will get up,
while wicked people will stumble into misfortune.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be happy when your enemy falls.
Do not let your heart celebrate when he stumbles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do, the Lord will see it and consider it evil,
and he will turn his anger away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not fret about evildoers.
Do not be jealous of wicked people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because an evil person has no future.
The lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fear the Lord, my son, and also the king.
Do not associate with those who are rebellious,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because their disaster will take place suddenly.
Who knows what ruin the Lord and the king will cause?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These sayings also are by the wise:
To show partiality when administering justice is not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If anyone says to a guilty person, “You are innocent,”
people will curse him. Nations will denounce him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, it will be pleasant for those who convict the guilty.
A wonderful blessing will come upon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Someone who gives a straight answer gives a kiss on the lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Prepare your work outside,
and get things ready for yourself in the fields.
Afterward, build your house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause.
Do not practice deception with your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not think, “I will do to him what he did to me.
I will pay the man back for what he did.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I passed by a lazy man’s field
and by a vineyard that belonged to a senseless man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It was overgrown with thistles
and covered with weeds.
Its stone wall was broken down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I saw this, I took it to heart.
I observed and learned a lesson:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A little sleep, a little slumber,
a little folding of the hands to rest—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and poverty will come on you like a prowler,
and scarcity will come like a warrior.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These also are the proverbs of Solomon,
which the men of King Hezekiah of Judah compiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It brings glory to God to hide a matter,
but it brings glory to kings to investigate a matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As heaven is high and earth is deep,
so there is no searching the heart of kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remove impurities from silver,
and a vessel can be cast by a silversmith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remove a wicked person from a king’s presence,
and his throne will be established with righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not honor yourself in a king’s presence.
Do not stand in a place reserved for great people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because it is better to be told, “Come up here,”
than for you to be humiliated before a ruler
    whom your eyes have seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be in a hurry to go to court.
Otherwise, what will you do afterward,
when your neighbor humiliates you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Argue your case with your neighbor,
but do not reveal someone else’s secret.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do, the person who hears it will shame you,
and your bad reputation will never leave you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A word spoken at the right time
    is like golden apples in silver settings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To ears that listen, a wise person’s correction
    is like a gold ring or like jewelry made of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To those who send him, a trustworthy messenger
    is like cooling snow on a warm day during harvest.
He refreshes his masters’ spirits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who brags about a gift that is never given
    is like clouds and wind that bring no rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By patience a ruler can be persuaded,
and a soft tongue can break a bone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When you find honey, eat only what you need.
Otherwise you will be filled with it and vomit it up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not set foot in your neighbor’s house too often.
If you do, he will have too much of you and hate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who gives false testimony against his neighbor
    is a club, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Confidence in an unfaithful person during a time of crisis
    is like a broken tooth or a lame foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Singing songs to a despondent heart
    is like taking off a coat on a cold day
    or like vinegar on baking soda.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If your enemy is hungry, give him something to eat.
If he is thirsty, give him something to drink,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because you will heap burning coals on his head,
and the Lord will repay you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A north wind gives birth to rain,
and a whispering tongue gives birth to angry faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better to live on the corner of a roof
than in a home shared with a nagging wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Good news from a distant country is
like cold water for a weary soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A righteous person who is swayed by the wicked
is a muddied spring or a polluted fountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eating too much honey is not good,
and people seeking their own glory is not glorious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who lacks self-control
is like a broken-down city without a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like snow during summer and rain during the harvest,
so honor is not appropriate for a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a migrating bird or a flying swallow,
so an undeserved curse does not come to rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A whip is for horses, a bridle for donkeys,
and a rod for the backs of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not answer a fool according to his folly.
If you do, you yourself will become like him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Answer a fool according to his folly.
If you do not, he will consider himself wise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is like cutting off your own feet or drinking violence
when a person sends messages in the hand of a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The legs of a lame person dangle.
So does a proverb in the mouth of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Giving honor to a fool is
    like tying a stone in a slingshot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A proverb in the mouth of a fool
    is like a thorn in a drunkard’s hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One who hires a fool or someone just passing by
    is like an archer who wounds at random.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a dog returns to his vomit,
so a fool repeats his stupidity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you seen a person who is wise in his own eyes?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lazy person says, “There’s a ferocious lion in the street.
There’s a lion in the public square!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A door turns on its hinges,
and a lazy person turns on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lazy person buries his hand in a dish,
but he is too tired to return it to his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lazy person considers himself wiser
than seven people who answer sensibly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A passerby who meddles in a quarrel that is not his
is like a person who grabs a dog by the ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A person who deceives his neighbor and then says, “I was only joking,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: is like a madman who shoots firebrands and deadly arrows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When there is no more wood, a fire goes out,
and without gossip, a quarrel dies down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As charcoal is to hot embers and as wood is to fire,
so a quarrelsome person is to igniting a fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Words of a gossip are like food that is easy to swallow.
They go down to the depths of one’s heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fervent lips and an evil heart
are like a glaze covering a clay pot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With his lips a person hides his hatred,
but he hides deceit inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When his voice sounds gracious, do not believe him,
because seven abominations are in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His hatred covers itself with deceit,
but his evil will be revealed in the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The person who digs a pit will fall into it.
The person who rolls away a stone—it will roll back over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lying tongue hates those it crushes,
and a smooth mouth causes ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
because you do not know what a day may produce.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let someone else praise you, not your own mouth—
a stranger, not your own lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A stone is heavy and sand is a burden,
but aggravation from a stubborn fool is heavier than both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cruel wrath and a flood of anger are devastating,
but who can stand up against jealousy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Open correction is better than concealed love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wounds from someone who loves you can be trusted,
but the kisses of someone who hates you are too much.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A satisfied appetite refuses honey,
but to a hungry appetite, everything bitter tastes sweet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who wanders from his place
    is like a bird that wanders from its nest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Olive oil and incense bring joy to a heart,
and the sweetness of a friend comes from his sincere advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not abandon your friend or your father’s friend,
and do not go to your brother’s house when disaster strikes you.
A neighbor who is near is better than a brother who is far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart,
so that I may answer anyone who taunts me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sensible person sees trouble and hides,
but naïve people keep going and pay the penalty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take the garment of someone who guarantees a loan for a stranger.
Keep it when someone pledges it on behalf of an immoral woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When someone blesses his neighbor in a loud voice early in the morning,
    it will be regarded as a curse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Constantly dripping water on a rainy day
and a nagging wife are alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Trying to hold her back is like holding back the wind,
like grasping oil with your right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron sharpens iron,
and a man sharpens the insight of his friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who tends a fig tree eats its fruit,
and a person who takes care of his master will be honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As water reflects a person’s face,
so a person’s heart reflects the person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Death and Destruction are never satisfied,
and a person’s eyes are never satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A crucible is for refining silver and a smelter is for gold,
and a person is tested by his praise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if you grind a stubborn fool
    like grain with a mortar and pestle,
his stupidity will not leave him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be certain that you know the condition of your flock very well.
Pay attention to your herds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because wealth is not forever,
nor does a crown pass from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The hay is removed and new growth appears,
and grass from the mountains is gathered in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lambs provide wool for your clothing,
and the price of the field can be earned from the goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked flee even though no one is pursuing them,
but the righteous are bold like a lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A rebellious land has many rulers,
but one man with understanding and knowledge provides stability.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A poor man who oppresses the poor
    is a driving rain that leaves no food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who abandon the law praise the wicked,
but those who keep the law oppose them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Evil men do not understand justice,
but those who seek the Lord understand everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better a poor person who walks in his integrity
    than a rich person who is hypocritical.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The son who keeps the law has understanding,
but a companion of gluttons brings shame upon his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who increases his wealth by piling up interest
    gathers it for someone who is generous to the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who turns his ear away from the law—
    even his prayer is an abomination.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who leads the upright along an evil way
will fall into his own pit,
but people of integrity will inherit good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wealthy person is wise in his own eyes,
but a needy person with understanding will expose him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous triumph, there is much celebration,
but when the wicked rise to power, people hide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who conceals his sins will not prosper,
but one who confesses and abandons them will receive mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blessed is the person who always is afraid of sin,
but one who hardens his heart will fall into calamity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wicked ruler over a poor people
    is a growling lion or a charging bear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a ruler lacks understanding, there will be much oppression,
but one who hates ill-gotten gain prolongs his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person haunted by the guilt of bloodshed
    will be a fugitive until he goes down to the pit.
No one should offer him support.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who walks with integrity will be saved,
but a person whose ways are crooked will fall all at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who works his land will have plenty of food,
but whoever pursues fantasies will have plenty of poverty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A trustworthy person has many blessings,
but a person in a hurry to get rich will not go unpunished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Showing favoritism is not good,
but a man may sin for a piece of bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A tightfisted person is in a hurry to get rich,
but he does not know that poverty is coming his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the end a person who corrects someone will find more favor
    than a person with a flattering tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who robs his father and his mother
and says, “It’s not a sin,” is no better than a vandal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A greedy person stirs up strife,
but a person who trusts in the Lord will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who trusts in his own ideas is a fool,
but a person who walks in wisdom will be kept safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who gives to the poor will lack nothing,
but a person who closes his eyes to them will receive many curses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked rise to power, people go into hiding,
but when the wicked perish, the righteous increase.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who remains stiff-necked after many rebukes
    will be broken suddenly, and there will be no cure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous increase, the people rejoice,
but when a wicked man rules, the people groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,
but one who visits prostitutes destroys his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A king brings stability to a land by justice,
but one who accepts bribes tears it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who flatters his neighbor
    is spreading a net for his steps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An evil man sets a trap with his sin,
but a righteous person sings and rejoices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A righteous person acknowledges the rights of the poor,
but a wicked person does not understand such knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Scoffers stir up a city,
but wise people turn away anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a wise person seeks justice from a stubborn fool,
the fool rants and laughs, and there is no peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bloodthirsty people hate anyone with integrity,
but upright people seek to save his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fool vents all his emotions,
but a wise person calmly restrains them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a ruler listens to lies,
all his officials become wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A poor person and an oppressor have this in common:
The Lord gives light to the eyes of both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a king judges poor people with truth,
his throne will be established permanently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A rod used for discipline gives wisdom,
but an undisciplined child disgraces his mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked increase, sin increases,
but the righteous will see their downfall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Discipline your son, and he will give you rest.
He will give delight to your soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Without prophetic vision, a people is unrestrained,
but a people which follows the law is blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A servant cannot be disciplined with words.
Although he understands, he shows no response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you seen a person who is hasty with his words?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone pampers his servant from the time he is young,
later on he will have grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A hothead stirs up a fight,
and a quick-tempered person commits many sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person’s arrogance will humble him,
but a humble spirit will attain honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The partner of a thief hates his own life.
He hears the oath, but he does not reveal anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Being afraid of a man sets a trap,
but a person who trusts in the Lord will be secure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many people seek a ruler’s favor,
but a person gets justice from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An unjust person is disgusting to righteous people,
but one whose way is upright is disgusting to the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of Agur son of Jakeh. An oracle.
This man declares:
I am weary, God. I am weary, God, and worn out,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I am too unreasoning to be a man.
I do not even possess human understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have not learned wisdom.
I do not have knowledge of the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has gone up to heaven and come down?
Who has gathered the wind in the palms of his hands?
Who has wrapped the water in a garment?
Who has set up all the ends of the earth?
What is his name and the name of his son?
Tell me if you know!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every word of God has been refined.
He is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not add to his words.
If you do, he will correct you,
and you will be shown to be a liar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Two things I have asked from you.
Do not keep them from me before I die:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Keep worthless speech and lies far from me.
Do not give me poverty or riches.
Give me food in the amount that is right for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Too much, and I may feel satisfied and deny you
and say, “Who is the Lord?”
Too little, and I may become poor and steal
and profane the name of my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not slander a servant to his master.
If you do, he will curse you,
and you will be found guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a type of person who curses his father
and does not bless his mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This person is pure in his own eyes,
but he is not washed from his filth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This person—how lofty his eyes, how high his eyelids!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This person—his teeth are swords,
and his fangs are knives.
He uses them to devour oppressed people from the earth
and poor people from among humanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The leech has two daughters: Give! Give!
Three things are never satisfied.
Four never say, “Enough!”:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the grave,
    a closed womb,
    land that is never satisfied with water,
    and fire that never says, “Enough!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An eye that mocks its father
and despises the obedience due its mother—
ravens of the valley will peck it out,
and young vultures will eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Three things are too wonderful for me,
and four I cannot understand:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the way of an eagle in the sky,
    the way of a snake on a rock,
    the way of a ship on the high seas,
    and the way of a man with a virgin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the way of a woman who commits adultery:
She eats and wipes her mouth,
and she says, “I haven’t done anything wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Three things make the earth tremble.
There are four things it cannot endure:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a servant when he becomes king,
    an arrogant fool when he is filled with food,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a woman who is hated when she is married,
    and a slave girl when she replaces her master’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Four things are small on the earth,
yet they are wiser than the wisest people:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ants are a species without strength,
    but they store their food in summer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rock badgers are a species without power,
    but they make their home in a cliff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Locusts have no king,
    but they all march ahead in ranks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lizards can be caught in your hands,
    but they live in kings’ palaces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Three things strut impressively.
Four walk with dignity:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a lion, which is the mightiest among the animals,
    does not turn away from anything,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a strutting rooster,
    a male goat,
    and a king reviewing his troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have acted like a fool by exalting yourself,
or if you have been scheming,
put your hand over your mouth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because just as pressing milk produces cheese,
and pressing a nose brings forth blood,
so pressing one’s anger produces a fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of Lemuel, a king.
An oracle that his mother used, to teach him discipline:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What are you doing, my son!
What are you doing, son from my womb!
What are you doing, son of my vows!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not give your strength to women.
Do not give your ways to those who destroy kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not for kings, Lemuel,
it is not for kings to drink wine,
nor for rulers to crave beer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If he does, he will drink and forget what is decreed.
He will change the legal rights of all the oppressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give beer to someone who is perishing
and wine to one whose soul is bitter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will drink and forget his poverty,
and he will no longer remember his trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Speak up for those who cannot speak.
Speak for the rights of all those who are defenseless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Speak up, judge fairly,
and defend the oppressed and needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can find a wife with strong character?
Her value is greater than that of gems.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband’s heart trusts her,
and he never lacks wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She does good for him and not evil
    all the days of her life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She obtains wool and flax.
She eagerly works it with her hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is like merchant ships.
She brings her food from far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She rises while it is still night.
She gives food to her household.
She gives their share to her female servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She considers a field and acquires it.
From her own income, she plants a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She wraps strength around her waist like a belt,
and she makes her arms strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She realizes that she makes a good profit.
Her lamp does not go out at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She stretches out her hands for the distaff,
and the palms of her hands grasp the spindle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She opens the palm of her hand to the oppressed,
and she stretches out her hands to the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She does not fear for her household on account of snow,
because her entire household is clothed in scarlet clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes bedspreads for herself.
Fine linen and purple cloth are her clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband is known at the city gates,
where he sits with the elders of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes linen garments and sells them,
and she delivers belts to the merchants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strength and honor are her clothing,
and she laughs at the days to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She opens her mouth with wisdom,
and kind instruction is on her tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She keeps a close eye on the conduct of her household,
and she does not eat bread that she did not work for.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her children rise up and bless her.
Her husband rises up and praises her:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Many daughters show strong character,
but you have surpassed all of them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charm is deceptive, and beauty is vapor that vanishes,
but a woman who fears the Lord should be praised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give her credit for the fruit of her hands,
and let her accomplishments praise her in the city gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator
